memberdef.definition: SplinePolarFootFinder< TimeStepper, LogicalToPhysicalMapping, LogicalToPseudoPhysicalMapping, SplineRThetaBuilder, SplineRThetaEvaluatorConstBound >::SplinePolarFootFinder
memberdef.argsstring: (TimeStepper const &time_stepper, LogicalToPhysicalMapping const &logical_to_physical_mapping, LogicalToPseudoPhysicalMapping const &logical_to_pseudo_physical_mapping, SplineRThetaBuilder const &builder_advection_field, SplineRThetaEvaluatorConstBound const &evaluator_advection_field, double epsilon=1e-12)
memberdef.name: SplinePolarFootFinder

briefdescription.para: Instantiate a time integration method for the advection operator.

parameterdescription.para: The time integration method used to solve the characteristic equation (ITimeStepper).
The mapping from the logical domain to the physical domain.
The mapping from the logical domain to the pseudo-physical domain.
The spline builder which computes the spline representation of the advection field.
The B-splines evaluator to evaluate the advection field.
$ \varepsilon $ parameter used for the linearisation of the advection field around the central point.

memberdef.definition: void SplinePolarFootFinder< TimeStepper, LogicalToPhysicalMapping, LogicalToPseudoPhysicalMapping, SplineRThetaBuilder, SplineRThetaEvaluatorConstBound >::operator()
memberdef.argsstring: (FieldRTheta< CoordRTheta > feet, DVectorConstFieldRTheta< X, Y > advection_field, double dt) const final
memberdef.name: operator()

briefdescription.para: Advect the feet over $ dt $.

detaileddescription.para: From the advection field in the physical index range, compute the advection field in the right index range an compute its B-splines coefficients. Then, use the given time integration method (time_stepper) to solve the characteristic equation over $ dt $.

parameterdescription.para: On input: the mesh points. On output: the characteristic feet.
The advection field in the physical index range.

memberdef.definition: void SplinePolarFootFinder< TimeStepper, LogicalToPhysicalMapping, LogicalToPseudoPhysicalMapping, SplineRThetaBuilder, SplineRThetaEvaluatorConstBound >::is_unified
memberdef.name: is_unified

briefdescription.para: Check if the values at the centre point are the same.

detaileddescription.para: For polar geometry, to ensure continuity at the centre point, we have to be sure that all the points for $ r = 0 $ have the same value. This function check if for $ r= 0 $, the values $ \forall \theta $ are the same.

parameterdescription.para: A table of values we want to check if the centre point has an unique value.

memberdef.definition: void SplinePolarFootFinder< TimeStepper, LogicalToPhysicalMapping, LogicalToPseudoPhysicalMapping, SplineRThetaBuilder, SplineRThetaEvaluatorConstBound >::unify_value_at_centre_pt
memberdef.name: unify_value_at_centre_pt

briefdescription.para: Replace the value at $ (r=0, \theta)$ point by the value at $ (r=0,0) $ for all $ \theta $.

detaileddescription.para: For polar geometry, to ensure continuity at the centre point, we have to be sure that all the points for $ r = 0 $ have the same value. As the computation of the values of a table can induces machine errors, this function is useful to reset the values at the central point at the same value.

parameterdescription.para: The table of values we want to unify at the central point.

briefdescription.para: A class to find the foot of the characteristics on the $ (r,\theta) $ plane.

detaileddescription.para: The natural advection domain is the physical domain, where the studied equation is given. However, not all the mappings used are analytically invertible and inverting the Jacobian matrix of the mapping could be costly and could introduce numerical errors. That is why, we also introduce a pseudo-Cartesian domain.
More details can be found in Edoardo Zoni's article (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcp.2019.108889).

parameterdescription.para: A child class of ITimeStepper providing a time integration method.
A mapping from the logical domain to the physical domain.
A mapping from the logical domain to the domain where the advection is carried out. This may be a pseudo-physical domain or the physical domain itself.
A 2D SplineBuilder to construct a spline on a polar domain.
A 2D SplineEvaluator to evaluate a spline on a polar domain. A boundary condition must be provided in case the foot of the characteristic is found outside the domain.
